resource.chars:
Description of the position of the 'Discovery'

<u>Feb 22<sup>nd<sup>. 1903<u>

Mounts Erebus & Terror be approximately east & west
connected by a long saddle backed, snow covered ridge
4000 or 5000ft in height; from the foot of which
shifting to the westward of its centre another <sup>low narrow<sup> ridge
runs at right angles to the Southward, ending <sup>at<sup> some
8 or 9 miles in Cape Armitage

This forms two large open bays, that to the Eastward
being almost completely filled by the barrier in, whilst
that to the westward forms a shelter in which
the ship at present lies: glaciers descend into
both bays.
The accompanying tracing shows <s>[very?]<s> approximately the geographical situation

On Feb 8<sup>th<sup> 1902 we found a considerable amount 
of pack close to the South Victoria Coast and 
parsing close to the glacier snout <sup>(marked 'old [debris strewn?] ice' <s>in sketch<s>)<sup> shown in the 
tracing, stood up along the edge of the fast ice
in comparatively clear water to the Hut Point

The ship was secured <sup>at first<sup> on the northern side of Hut Point but the ice continued to break away with such
rapidity that we were soon able to bring her 
round into better shelters on the South side of the Point

The ice that broke away at this season was from 5
to 7 feet in thickness in the main floe<s>s<s> but thicker
close inshore
